application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
description:
T.1 Cherry - Remove large limb overhanging service road and other major deadwood.
T.2 Cherry - Remove large fallen limb resting on adjacent fence and other major deadwood.
T.3 Silver Birch - 3m Lateral reduction from house, 20% crown thin to suitable growth points, crown lift to 3m from ground level & deadwood.
T.4 Silver Birch - 20% Crown thin, crown lift to 3m from ground level & deadwood.
T.5 Cherry - 3m Lateral reduction from house, 20% crown thin to suitable growth points, crown lift to 3m from ground level & deadwood.
T.6 Cherry - 3m Lateral reduction from house, 20% crown thin to suitable growth points & deadwood.

decision_conditions:
1. Under the provisions of sections 206 and 213 of the Act, the owner of the land upon which the above tree(s) are to be removed is under a duty to plant one replacement tree of appropriate size and species, per tree under TPO removed according to the above list. These should be planted as close to the original tree(s) as possible unless otherwise agreed with the Council's Tree Officer. The replacement trees should be planted within the first planting season (Oct 1st - April 30th) following the proposed removals.

2. The size of the tree shall be a standard with a height of 2.50 metres, a minimum stem height of 1.75 metres and a girth of 8cm to 10cm to conform with BS 3936 Part 1 (1992).

3. Any replacement trees which within a period of five years from planting are removed, die or become seriously damaged/diseased shall be replaced within the next planting season (Oct 1st to April 30th) with trees of similar amenity value.

Any replacement planting should be carried out with due consideration for overhead and underground services, property boundaries, buildings and potential maintenance. The eventual size of a specimen and the nature of its rooting structure should also be taken into account when choosing where to plant, in order to achieve the best result for your site.

The following will be suitable replacement species:

(a) Purple Birch (Betula pendula 'Purpurea') as replacement for T.2.
(b) Paper Birch (Betula papyrifera) as replacement for T.1

I have to warn you that if one of the above specified replacements is not planted by the end of the first planting season (Oct 1st to April 30th) following the proposed removals, a notice may be served under section 207 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). However, I trust that such action will not be necessary and I look forward to receiving your full cooperation in this matter. Please ensure that you inform the Council's Tree Officer (ben.morgan@kingston.gov.uk) with the provision of a photo once the replanting has taken place.

T.1 Cherry - Fell.
T.2 Cherry - Fell.
T.3 Swedish Birch - Remove lowest 4 limbs back to trunk only.
T.4 Swedish Birch - Remove lowest 4 limbs back to trunk only.
T.5 Cherry - Fell.
T.6 Cherry - Remove 3 lowest minor limbs back to trunk, crown lift remaining secondary growth uniformally to 2.5m from ground level as measured from base of tree, 10% crown thin & remove deadwood.

Works are insufficient to address health and safety problems of T.1 & T.2 and are excessive to the remaining trees T.3, T.4 & T.6. T.5 is severly suppressed, is not covered by the TPO and should not be retained.

The fee required for your joint planning application is £ 509.00. We acknowledge the receipt of £256.00, please pay the outstanding balance of £251.00. Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website or our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002.

Note: The application for 38 Hollybush Road (25/00236/HOU) has not been withdrawn or closed, so we cannot tranfer the fee from application 25/00236/HOU to this application 25/00225/FUL
Please amend any supporting documents such ad fire statement to reflect the joint application '38 and 40 Hollybush Road' if necessary.

Please submit the validation check list with updated information, the submitted checklist is for householder, as it is a joint application for full planning permission. Please check the new local list in our website before filling the validation checklist.
The new local list and validation checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.

--- Officer Report ---

Introduction
This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  

Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Act, Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.

Consultation 
Kingston and North Kingston Neighbourhood CAAC - Objection. Refer to appraisal of 24/02379.
Heritage Officer - The applicant removed the solar panels. No objection to the revisions subject to a pre-commencement condition.

Proposal
Fenestration alteration, installation of ventilation grilles. Replacement of rainwater goods with cast iron. Roof work with new slate tiles in existing pitched roof, new deck on rear top flat roof and first floor flat roof including roof covering. Brickwork repairment, installation of solar panels HVAC system and plant equipment. Internal alteration and advert.

The building is a Grade II statutorily listed building. Church Street (East Side),Kingston, List ref: 1184118, List date: 06/10/1983

Assessment
The application is assessed against section 16 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990.

The section states that

(1 )Subject to the previous provisions of this Part, the local planning
authority or, as the case may be, the Secretary of State may grant or refuse
an application for listed building consent and, if they grant consent, may
grant it subject to conditions.

(2)in considering whether to grant listed building consent for any works the
local planning authority or the Secretary of State shall have special regard
to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of
special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.

(3)Any listed building consent shall (except in so far as it otherwise
provides) enure for the benefit of the building and of all persons for the time
being interested in it.

The proposal would include fenestration alteration, installation of ventilation grilles, replacement of rainwater goods with cast iron, roof work with new slate tiles in existing pitched roof, new deck on rear top flat roof and first floor flat roof including roof covering, brickwork repairment, internal alteration and advertisement for signs and logo.

The applicant removed the solar panel element during the course of the application. Council's Heritage Officer was consulted and no objection was raised subject to a pre-commencement condition for submission and approval of windows, doors and louvre vents details.It is considered that the proposed works would preserve the building's appearance and special architectural features and its historic interest.

It is considered that the proposal would meet the test of section 16 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990.

It is recommended that the Listed Building application be granted.

Details of the Application Submission
In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.

https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

--- Informatives ---

Positive and Proactive
In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Officer Report

Application Site
The site comprises a detached dwelling located within the Coombe Hill Conservation Area, Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character and 2.5 Coombe Hill Area of Archaeological Significance.

The site is covered by a TPO group order.

Proposal 
Erection of an external covered BBQ Area (Retrospective)

Representations 
4 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations have been received 

Consultations
Maldens and Coombe Conservation area Advisory Committee - no objections

The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development;
- The impact of the development on the Heritage Assets;
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,
-Trees;
- Fire Safety. 

Character and Appearance
When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer Comment: The current application relates to the application ref 24/02054/HOU for 'Replacement of existing timber front door and side lights with composite door and side lights. Erection of covered BBQ area to rear.' refused on 08.11.2024 due to the adverse impact of the proposed front door on the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Officers raised no injections to the proposed BBQ area.

The proposed BBQ area as per submitted plans is the same in terms of scale, materials and siting as the one assessed for the previous scheme ref 24/02054/HOU. 

Given the proposed design, materials and its siting that will not be visible with the existing street scene, the proposal is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area.

Heritage Assets
Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  
In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph  203 of the NPPF 2023 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.       
                                                                                                              
Paragraph 205 of NPPF 2023 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.   
                                           
Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.

Paragraph 209 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.

Officer comment: The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as the special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: The estate and hinterland to the demolished Coombe Warren, containing several mid 19th century properties by architect George Devey and other large interesting 20th century houses in a spacious landscaped setting, adjoining Coombe Hill Golf Course.

The application property is not listed or locally listed, but given the high quality materials and design it contributes positively to the conservation area. 

Having regard to the above, Officers conclude that the proposal would be in-keeping with the host dwelling, the Coombe Hill Conservation Area and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  not result in harm to the significance of the Heritage Assets.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, the existing greenery along the common boundary with No 149 and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Protected Trees
The proposal, given its scale and siting, would not adversely affect the protected trees.
It is noted that the Tree Officer raised no objections to the arboricultural information submitted for the previous application ref 24/02054/HOU, the current BBQ area and the arboricultural information are identical to the previous scheme. 

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Planning Fire Safety Strategy, which is considered to be acceptable. 

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
